link.title: Review: The Vow

link.Abstract: The Canadian actress has returned to her romantic roots with new drama The Vow.
link.title: Rachel McAdams remembers Vow

link.title: Vintage year for Genie Awards

content.div:
LOS ANGELES - Scott Speedman has been on the verge of stardom since leaving Toronto for the lure of Hollywood more than a decade ago.

He's still biding his time, hoping for his breakout. But patience isn't just a virtue for him; it's a necessity.

"I am 36 now, so I can have a little more perspective about this town," says the actor a Beverly Hills hotel. "But you can see why people go off the rails here, just from the pressure of trying to keep up with the Joneses."

No hard partying from this handsome talent, however.

How does he avoid it? He maintains that the best way to avoid "degeneration when insecurity runs amok" is to surround yourself with "good people," and to treat your career like a profession, not a lifestyle.

He also continues to be a laid-back kind of actor, who usually thinks before he speaks. "That sort of Hollywood bravado goes a long way for some people, but, for better or worse, I just don't have it."

On an optimistic note, Speedman has two new films, which might help him in his quest to elevate his standing.

He plays the title character in the Canadian crime biopic, Edwin Boyd: Citizen Gangster, which will be released in the U.S. as Citizen Gangster, in April.

More immediately, Speedman co-stars with Rachel McAdams and Channing Tatum in the romantic drama, The Vow, which opened Feb. 10 to decent reviews and a No. 1 weekend at the box office.

Directed by Michael Sucsy, the movie features Speedman as Jeremy, a suave businessman who's soon to be caught up in a love triangle when his former girlfriend Paige (McAdams) ends up in a coma after a car accident.

When she finally regains consciousness, she suffers from severe memory loss, and reverts to her old ways, which is great for her one-time boyfriend Jeremy, but not so pleasant for her husband Leo (Tatum).

Paige doesn't recognize Leo, nor the unconventional lifestyle she leads with him, so she slowly drifts away from him, and back into Jeremy's arms. With Paige's upper-class father (Sam Neill) and mother (Jessica Lange) manipulating their daughter, all seems lost for Leo until he tries win her back.

So is Speedman's Jeremy the bad guy? Sucsy believes the character is more complex.

"What I liked about Scott is that he's a leading-man-type actor," says the director. "And when his Jeremy, who is likable, competes with Channing's Leo, you are never quite sure how it's going to turn out."

Speedman takes the praise in stride. "It's just a matter of getting those lead jobs now," he says, adding of his role in The Vow:"I tried to play him as real as possible, and not make him a moustache-twirling villain, because it doesn't help the story to be that way."

Complementing the performances by McAdams and Tatum was important to him, as well.

"They are both low-key and never over the top, and I tried to match that to suit the film's tone," he said.

The good and bad news was that The Vow was filmed in Speedman's hometown of Toronto (substituting for Chicago); good, because he got to reconnect with friends, and bad for the same "distracting" reasons.

From 1998 to 2002, Speedman established himself in L.A. with his portrayal of the brooding college student Ben Covington opposite Keri Russell in the series, Felicity. During that high-profile stretch, he even fit in a co-starring film role in 2000's Duets with Gwyneth Paltrow.

He also showed up in 2003's Underworld and the 2006 sequel, Underworld: Evolution, and, in between, had a part in the 2005 crime thriller, xXx: The Next Level. He received decent notices for his roles in 2008's thriller, The Strangers, Atom Egoyan's Adoration the same year, and for his co-starring part in the 2010 film version of Mordecai Richler's novel, Barney's Version.

Speedman is hoping his part as 1940s and '50s bank robber, Edwin Boyd, will be seen beyond Canada when the movie rolls out in April, after its successful premiere at the 2011 Toronto International Film Festival.

"I did all the annoying and boring actor research, but the Boyd character isn't that much of a public figure," says Speedman, who has been nominated for a best-actor Genie Award for his performance. "I just did the work and let it fly. Boyd was charming, but I play him a little more edgy."

entry.title: Vintage year for Genie Awards

link.Abstract: The star-studded list of this year's Genie Award nominees includes Michelle Williams, Michael Fassbender, Viggo Mortensen and Rachel Weisz.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Rachel Weisz has been nominated for a Genie Award for best actress for her role in The Whistleblower.
link.title: Rachel Weisz has been nominated for a Genie Award for best actress for her role in The Whistleblower.

link.Abstract: Franco Quebec films have handily dominated the past two editions of the Genie Awards - thanks to Polytechnique and Incendies. But Quebec might not dominate the Canadian film awards ceremony this year.
link.title: Quebec films lead Genie nominations pack

link.Abstract: Art and commerce walked the aisle together Tuesday as the Toronto International Film Festival Group announced this year's top Canadian films.
link.title: Festival releases Canada's annual Top 10 films

link.Abstract: Margaret Atwood's prescient tales of debt, Chinese pugilists and videogame developers will headline Canada's presence at this year's Sundance Film Festival.
link.title: Sundance Canadians

link.Abstract: When Sarah Polley was 18 years old, the first film she wanted to make was an adaptation of Margaret Atwood's historical novel, Alias Grace.
link.title: Polley to film Atwood's Alias Grace

link.Abstract: A hometown boy and a sentimental throwback to the silent era won over Vancouver's critical hearts, as Seth Rogen picked up a best-supporting-actor nod, and Michel Hazanavicius's The Artist dominated the Vancouver Film Critics Circle nominations, announced Monday.
link.title: Vancouver film critics love The Artist, Jessica Chastain
